Alia is a single mother looking after her seven sons and daughters after her husband passed away. One of her sons, Odai, 20 years old, has recently enrolled in a university to study to become a school teacher. Alia is now applying for an educational loan to pay for Odai's semester fees.

loans.use: to pay for her son's semester fees.

loans.name: Marilu Del Carmen

texts.es: La señora Marilu habita en el municipio de Ticuantepe junto a su esposo e hijos, mujer trabajadora, desde muy joven a luchado para darle mejores condiciones a sus hijos, ella es comerciante vende Ropa nueva y de segunda, con este credito comprara Pacas de Ropa de Segunda para niños, Adolescentes y Adultos ya que la demanda de sus clientes esta aumentando. Agradece el Apoyo de Afodenic y  Fondos Kiva.
texts.en: Marilu lives in the municipality of Ticuantepe with her husband and children, a working woman struggling from an early age. In order to provide better conditions for her children she is a merchant selling new and secondhand clothing. Using this loan she will buy bundles of secondhand clothing for children, teenagers, and adults as the demand from her customers is increasing. She is grateful for the help from Afodenic and Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy bundles of secondhand clothing for her business.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 43 years old and lives in the town of Nyendo in the Masaka region of Uganda. He is married and has 2 children who are all currently in school. For the past 4 years, John  has been working hard to manage his bar, which sells soft drinks and alcohol. 

To help expand his business, John  has requested a loan of 2000000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more drinks such as beer, wine and spirits to sell. This will help John generate greater profits which will help generate income. John hopes that in the future he will be able to continue to improve the business. 

John is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like John who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy drinks such as beer, wine and spirits to sell

loans.name: Riyad

texts.en: Riyad is a 53 years old hardworking guy. He is father to five sons and daughters. Riyad has a carpentry business that he wants to enhance by purchasing new equipment that will increase the quality of works he does. This loan will allow him to do that.

loans.use: to bring new equipment for carpentry

loans.name: Thana'

texts.en: Thana’ is a 58 year old housewife. She has a small cosmetic sales business and has recently launched a tailoring and sewing business to increase her income. She is now applying for a loan to enhance her services by buying new thread and a better quality fabric.

loans.use: to buy new thread and a better quality fabric.

loans.name: Linda

texts.en:
Linda is a 44 year old conservative woman. She has asked her son Ramzi to take her place in the photo. 
She is the mother to three sons. She has a small tailoring business and also creates handmade embroidery. Linda primarily adds embroidery art to women’s dresses. She is applying for a loan to buy more sewing material and tools and to get a new sewing machine.

loans.use: to buy sewing material and tools

loans.name: Rola

texts.en: Rola is a 38 year old mother to two boys and two girls. While her husband is working at a hotel, she has started a small retail business at home selling home products. She is now applying for a loan to increase the quantity of housewares and decoration pieces that she offers for sale.

loans.use: to increase the quantity she has of housewares and decoration pieces.

loans.name: Goreth

texts.en:
Goreth is 29 years old and lives in the town of Kalisizo in the Masaka region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past seven years, Goreth has been working hard to manage her pharmacy.

To help expand her business, Goreth has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more medicines for sale, and it will help Goreth to generate greater profits and income. Goreth hopes that in the future she will be able to have a bigger business. 

Goreth is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Goreth who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more medicines to sell.

loans.name: Amneh

texts.en:
Amneh is a 54-year-old conservative woman; she asked her husband to appear in her loan photo in her place.

Amneh is the mother of one son and one daughter. They have an ice cream business where they make their own biscuit cones. Now Amneh wants to start making ice cream. She applied for this loan to purchase needed ingredients for testing before the spring and summer seasons start.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for making ice cream.

loans.name: Hayjar

texts.en: Hayjar is a 44-year-old mother of nine sons and daughters. She has a small business at home mixing perfumes. She is now applying for a loan to buy more materials, scents, and tools for enhancing her business.

loans.use: to get buy supplies for her perfume business.

loans.name: Gulsunda

texts.en:
Gulsunda, 35 years old, lives in Senaki with her 38-year-old husband Levan, parents, and three children who are going to school. Gulsunda requested loans from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but her requests were consistently rejected due to low income and the family’s poor living conditions.

Gulsunda sells perfume, buying at wholesale prices and selling with price markups to the local citizens. She also has a commercial space at the local market that she is renting out. Additionally, the family is persecuted, so they get a monthly income from the government. According to Credo estimations, the family belongs to the subsistence poor category.

Gulsunda requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. Her loan request was approved within the framework of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages the provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the country's rural poor, who do not have access to credit products because they are regarded as “high risk borrowers” due to low income. With the received credit Gulsunda wants to rent a small place in the center of the city to open a shop where she will sell souvenirs and other such products. She will buy at wholesale prices and sell with price markups. This will increase her monthly profit. Gulsunda will use part of the profit to develop her business and another part to provide better living conditions for her family.

loans.use: to rent a shop to sell souvenirs and other such products.

loans.name: Ratha

texts.en: Ratha is a 49-year-old housewife; her husband is a truck driver. She is caring for their three daughters and three sons. While being at home Ratha started a small business selling antique decoration pieces. She is now looking to enhance that business and include a few modern ones, and for that reason, she applied for this loan.

loans.use: to include modern decoration pieces in her inventory

loans.name: Maryam

texts.en: Maryam is a 34-year-old mother of five daughters and a son. She recently started a sewing business and acquired a small sewing machine. Now she is applying for a loan to purchase fabric, threads, and beads to enhance the quality of her work.

loans.use: to buy fabric, threads, and beads.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is 42 years old. He sells educational supplies such as text books, reading books, story books, pens, pencils, and mathematical sets. He has been in this business for the past ten years, and he is doing very well. He is a very dedicated and hardworking individual. 

He joined ID Ghana in 2007 through another member. He has since taken seven loans from ID and has been able to repay them without any default. He is applying for his eigth loan and needs 1,400 GHS to buy more educational supplies to sell to his customers in the Glefe community in Dansoman.

loans.use: to buy more educational products to sell.

loans.name: Development Ii Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Development II” group. They are small scale businesswomen based in Koidu, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit, and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Sia. Sia is 54; she was born in Tankoro in the Kono district. She is currently residing in Koidu with her husband and six children. Her husband is an electrician, and two of her children are attending secondary schools. Sia has been a businesswoman for many years now. She sells food in the market such as rice, onions, margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), salt, pepper, fish, and tomatoes. With her share of this loan, she is going to buy more food to sell.

loans.use: to buy food to sell in the market.

loans.name: Monawar

texts.en: Monawar is the mother of three sons. She has added blanket sales to her tailoring business to increase her income. Now Monawar is applying for another youth loan to buy new bed covers made from different material.

loans.use: to buy new bed covers for sale.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en: Fatuma is thankful because she has been able to educate her children using loans accessed through Ugafode and funded by Kiva lenders, Her children performed very well because they were not interrupted from their studies. She now wants another loan to pay tuition for her children. She is a hard-working and determined woman. She wants the relationship with UGAFODE and Kiva  to grow stronger and better.

loans.use: To pay school fees

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for repairing her husband's machine

loans.name: Obadia

texts.en:
Obadia is a 43-year-old second-hand jeans seller who resides at Glefe in Dansoman. He joined ID in 2009 and has been a member to date and is doing very well in his business.
 
He has been doing this business for five years now. He buys from Kantamato market in the capital and sells in the Dansoman community. 

This is his fifth loan with ID Ghana and he needs a loan of GHS 1,000 to buy more goods to sell to his customers.

loans.use: to buy more jeans for resale

loans.name: Honest Group

texts.en:
Kadiatu is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Kadiatu was born in a place called Tholie, in eastern Sierra Leone. She is 36 years of age. Kadiatu is married to a teacher, and the couple has one child who is attending primary school. For over five years now, Kadiatu has been selling shoes, slippers, and clothes. 

This is first loan that Kadiatu and her group members have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales, and consequently improve their living conditions. Kadiatu will use her share of the loan to expand her business; she will buy slippers and clothes in bulk to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy slippers and clothes in bulk to add to her current stock.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy local brew to sell.

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is 40 years old and lives in the town of Kyotera in the Masaka region of Uganda. He is married and has six children, five of whom are currently in school. For the past seven years, Richard has been working hard to manage his grocery store, which sells items like sugar, flour, and rice. 

To help expand his business, Richard has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more items for sale. This will help Richard to generate greater profits and meets his customers' needs. Richard hopes that in the future he will be able to start another business. 

Richard is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Richard who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more items for sale.

loans.name: St Thereza Group

texts.en:
Alex is a thirty-two-year-old married man with three children, living in Kasese, Uganda. For six years now he has been operating an electronics shop and also practices farming. 

The high cost of products and rental fees affect the business while his dream is to trade in solar products which are in high demand. Alex intends to use the loan to  buy electronics equipment to sell. He is a member of St Thereza group where each one guarantees the other in accessing a loan.

loans.use: to  buy electronics equipment to sell.

loans.name: Juliyasi

texts.en: Juliyasi is a married man with two children and resides in Kagadi, Uganda. He operates a produce business which he has run for ten years now. He also sells alcohol in order to earn extra income. He dreams of buying a big lorry to help him in the transportation of produce to markets and from suppliers despite challenges of inadequate capital. Juliyasi intends to use the loan to buy maize and coffee to sell.

loans.use: to buy maize and coffee to sell.

loans.name: Yerekun Gnini Group

texts.fr:
Les six  membres du groupe YEREKUN GNINI sont  des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 33  ans, et ont en moyenne  3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygamiques à SIEKOURANI un des villages de la commune de Loulouni cercle de Kadiolo (Sikasso) 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur troisième prêt avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Les prêts passés ont été correctement remboursés.
SALIMATA 1ère assise à gauche sur la photo, fait le commerce de lait frais à travers ce groupe de femmes YEREKUN GNINI. 
Elle compte acheter avec son prêt 170 litres  du lait frais. Elle s’approvisionne dans les parcs avoisinants du village de Siékourani. 
Elle les revend au  marché de Siékourani et au marché de Loulouni ville le jour de foire à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes au comptant. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 17.000 FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne .
texts.en:
The six members of the Yerekun Gnini group are married women averaging 33 years of age, with three children. They live mainly in polygamous families in Siekourani, a village in the Louloni commune, in the Kadio district, the the third administrative region of Mali (Sikasso).

They are on their third loan with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution, with the goal of meeting customer demand. The prior loans have been duly repaid.

Salimata, the first one seated on the left in the photo, is a group member who sells fresh milk. She plans to use her loan to buy 170 liters [about 45 gal] of fresh milk. She buys from local farms around the village of Siekourani. She sells at the Sikeourani market and the market in the town of Louloni on market days, to a customer base composed of both men and women, for cash.  She plans to achieve an average monthly  revenue of 17,000 West African francs, one part of which will be used to pay off her loan, and the other part for savings.

loans.use: to buy fresh milk.

loans.name: Rubina

texts.en:
Ms. Rubina is a 29-year-old married woman. Her husband is a government employee but his income is not sufficient to cover all of their household expenses. She has been running a business of trading clothing for the past two years to contribute to the family income. 

She purchases a variety of clothing from the main city and then sells it to the people of her community. She has become well-known for selling good quality clothing. Currently she is requesting a loan of PKR 20,000 from the Kashi Foundation to buy stock of different clothing for the next season. In this way, she will be able to earn more income through higher sales. She is in her fifth loan cycle; her repayment history is remarkable. She dreams to provide a quality education to her children.

loans.use: to buy stock of different clothing for the next season to meet the demand and preferences of her customers.

loans.name: Anty

texts.en:
Anty is 26 years old and lives in the town of Namutumba in the Iganga region of Uganda. For the past five years, Anty has worked hard to manage his business, in which he sells rice and posho. 

To help expand his business, Anty has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more produce, and will help Anty to generate greater profits and more income. Anty hopes that in the future he will be able to buy land. 

Anty is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Anty who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy produce.

loans.name: Abou

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Abou a 35 ans, marié et père de deux  enfants. Il réside avec sa famille à Bougoula Hameau, commune rurale de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Abou après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès,  s’est initié au domaine du commerce dont il dispose d’une boutique devant le domicile conjugal. Il  mène des activités d’achat et vente des articles divers (Cigarette, bonbon, allumette, Chewing Gum, lait en poudre, thé, sucre, savon, etc) il y’a maintenant six ans. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant six mois. Il est à son deuxième prêt individuel.
Monsieur  Abou vend ses marchandises au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Avec ce  nouveau prêt, il compte acheter 5 cartouches de Cigarettes différentes, 3 cartons du thé, 2 sacs du sucre, 5 paquets de bonbon, 10 paquet de Chewing-gum, 30 paquets d’allumettes et 10 cartons de savons. Il s’approvisionne auprès de commerçants grossistes de la place avant de les revendre en détail.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Abou is 35 years old, married, and a father of two. He lives with his family in Bougoula Hameau, a rural town in Sikasso (the third administrative district in the Republic of Mali).

After having tried several businesses without success, Mr. Abou taught himself how to run a business; he has a shop in front of his family home. He has been purchasing and selling assorted goods (cigarettes, candy, matches, chewing gum, powdered milk, tea, sugar, soap, etc.) for six years now. He is highly sought after by his customers for the quality of his products.

To satisfy his growing customer base, Mr. Abou decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso six months ago. He is on his second individual loan.

Mr. Abou sells his wares for cash and on credit to a group of customers made up of men and women.

With this new loan, he plans to purchase five cartons of various cigarettes, three boxes of tea, two bags of sugar, five packages of candy, 10 packages of chewing gum, 30 packages of matches, and 10 boxes of soap. Mr. Abou gets his supplies from market wholesalers prior to selling them at retail.

With this loan, Mr. Abou expects to turn a monthly profit of 100,000 CFA francs, which will be used to contribute to the family expenses and to pay the interest on his loan; the rest will be invested in his business.

loans.use: To purchase assorted goods.

loans.name: Sulai

texts.en:
Sulai is 42 years old and lives in the town of Namutumba in the Iganga region of Uganda. He is married and has three children. Two of them are currently in school. For the past four years, Sulai has been working hard to manage his retail business, in which he sells sugar, salt, match boxes and other items. 

To help expand his business, Sulai has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more items such as milk and salt to sell, and will help Sulai to generate greater profits and more income. Sulai hopes that in the future he will be able to increase his stock and grow his business. 

Sulai is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Sulai who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more items, such as milk and salt, to sell.

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is 45 years old. He trades in home appliances (CD, DVD player, television) in the Glefe community. 

He has in this business for the past five years and is doing very well. He joined ID in 2010 and doing very well.

He is an innovative, and very organized and hardworking individual who is also committed to all he does.

This is his seventh loan. Patrick needs GHS 1,200 to buy more goods to satisfy his customers in the Glefe community.

loans.use: to buy more DVD players and televisions to sell.

loans.name: Bashil

texts.en: Bashil is a married man, aged 53, who lives in Kagadi, Uganda. Due to his passion for agriculture he started a produce business four years ago. He has also purchased a milling machine. With the proceeds he has been able to build rental houses to supplement his produce business and has also continued to farm. Bashil dreams of buying a vehicle to help him transport the goods despite the challenges of bad weather and bad roads that affect his business. Bashil is requesting a loan to buy beans and maize to sell.

loans.use: to buy beans and maize to sell.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is 34 years old. She sells porridge “Koko” in the Glefe community. She has been doing this business for the past ten years and is doing very well.

She joined ID in 2010.

Janet is an innovative, very organized and hardworking individual who is also committed to all she does.

This is her sixth loan. She needs GHS 1,200 to buy more cereal to prepare enough porridge “koko” to satisfy her customers in the Glefe community

loans.use: to buy more millet and sugar for porridge to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Musa

texts.en:
Musa is 35 years old and lives in the town of Namutumba in the Iganga region of Uganda. He is married with three children. Two of them are currently in school. For the past five years, Musa has worked hard to manage his retail business, in which he sells sugar, salt, match boxes and other items. 

To help expand his business, Musa has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more sugar, salt, match boxes and other items, and will help Musa to generate greater profits to support his family. Musa hopes that in the future he will be able to meet his customers' needs. 

Musa is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Musa who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more sugar, salt, and matchboxes.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a 36-year-old woman who sells stoves. She resides at Opetekwei in Dansoman. She has been in this business for the past four years and is doing very well.

She joined ID Ghana in April 2011 through another beneficiary. Grace is a very dedicated individual and hardworking. 
She has taken three loans from ID Ghana. 

Grace is applying for her fourth loan and needs GHS 1,000 to buy more stoves to sell to her customers in the community.

loans.use: to buy more stoves to sell.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel is a 36-year-old photographer. He belongs to the Arise Group in Zone 6 in Dansoman. He joined Ghana ID in 2011.

Samuel has been in this business for the past five years. He serves his customers in and around Dansoman. 

He also takes both photos and videos at weddings, parties, anniversaries and the like. He is very dedicated and committed to his customers.

This is Samuel's sixth loan; he needs GHS 1,200 to purchase a video camera to serve his customers better.

loans.use: to buy a video camera.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is a 44-year-old seller of goods like milo, milk, rice and cooking oil. She is married to James who is a 45-year-old trader. They have three children. 
She resides at first stop in Dansoman.

In 2012, she needed capital to expand her small business and, through a friend, joined ID Ghana. Janet is hardworking, industrious and a committed individual. Since joining ID Ghana, she has been very faithful by repaying two loans in full.
 
This is her third loan and she needs GHS 1,000 to buy more goods to sell to her customers in the Dansoman community.

loans.use: to buy more milo, rice, milk and cooking oil to sell.

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
This is Theresa from Peace Group at Russia in Dansoman. She is 35 years old. Theresa has been a hairdresser for the past six years and is doing very well.

She always tells people good things about ID Ghana and how it has helped her overcome all her challenges in life. 

She is an innovative and hardworking individual who is committed to all she does. She has been with ID Ghana since 2008. 

This is Theresa's ninth loan; she needs GHS 1,000 to buy cream, wigs, and shampoo to serve her customers.

loans.use: to buy cream, wigs, shampoo for her customers.

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business selling fruits and vegetables in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 16000 PHP through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. to purchase more fruits and vegetables to sell to customers.

Lourdes successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

NWTF is re-listing Lourdes's business profile again in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more fruits and vegetables to sell to customers.

loans.name: Franklin Antonio

texts.es:
Frankin de 24 años de edad, casado con un hijo de nueve años  de edad. Originario de Managua, lugar que está ubicado en la zona central de país. Franklin se caracteriza por ser un hombre muy trabajador, responsables. Lamentablemente por falta de recursos económicos no pudo cursar una carrera universitaria, y se vio obligado  a trabajar desde temprana edad para aporta a los gastos del hogar. Por tanto lucha día a día para brindarle un futuro mejor  a su pequeño hijo.
Gracia a  su espíritu de emprendedor y sus ganas de salir adelante es que tiene por actividad económica la venta de productos varios  que consiste en vender, juguetes de niños pelotas inflables, carros, rompe cabezas, sillas de niños plásticas, calculadoras, peluches, planchas. Actividad que la desempeña de forma ambulante y por encargos, la rutina de trabajo de este hombre es de 12 horas diarias con un bulto de 30 kg ofreciendo su mercadería. Actividad que la desempeña con mucho gusto, ya que el sustento de su hijo. El objetivo del crédito es invertir en capital de trabajo y surtir su negocio en la compra y venta de  productos varios. Para que en un futuro no muy lejano pueda obtener mejores ingresos. Franklin agradece la ayuda que los inversionistas kiva le brindan a personas de escasos recursos y países pobre como es Nicaragua para tener un medio de trabajo digno.
texts.en:
Franklin is 24 years old and married with one child who is 9 years old.  He is originally from Managua, a place that is located in the central area of the country.  Franklin is characterized as being a very hardworking and responsible man.  Unfortunately due to a lack of economic resources he could not pursue a university education and he was forced to work from a very early age in order to contribute to the household expenses.  Therefore he struggles day to day to provide a better future for his young son.  

Thanks to his entrepreneurial spirit and his desire to get ahead he has as his economic activity the sale of various products that consist of children’s toys, inflatable balls, cars, puzzles, plastic children’s chairs, calculators, stuffed animals and irons.  He performs this work as a street merchant and by orders.  This man's work routine is 12 hours a day with a bundle of 30 kg offering his merchandise.  He carries out this activity with great pleasure as it is the sustenance for his son.  The purpose of this loan is to invest in working capital and stock his business in the buying and selling of the various products so that in a not-too-distant future he can obtain better income.  

Franklin is grateful for the help that the Kiva lenders offer to people of limited resources and poor countries like Nicaragua so that they have a way to work with dignity.

loans.use: to purchase various products such as children’s toys, inflatable balls, cars, puzzles, plastic children’s chairs, calculators, stuffed animals and irons.

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
Lilibeth is married with five children. She is 46 years old and lives in Kalasan, Pagadian City in the Philippines.

Lilibeth sells groceries to earn a living and has had this business for two years. Each month, she earns 5,000 doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of 14,900 to purchase more stock for her general store.                     

Lilibeth has been a member of PMPC for 5 years. In the future, Lilibeth hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock for her general store.

loans.name: Youssouf

texts.fr:
Né vers 1981 à Kai Youssouf  est un homme marié et père de quatre enfants, qui vit avec sa famille à Loulouni ville, une des  sous préfecture de Sikasso.
 Youssouf mène des activités de menuiserie métallique : soudure, fabrication et vente de  portes isoprènes + fenêtres +  chaises, il y a environ six  années. Il jouit d’une forte réputation dans cette activité et reçoit beaucoup de commandes, mais ses ressources ne peuvent pas lui permettre de les satisfaire. C’est ainsi, qu’il décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso. Il est à son quatrième prêt, les prêts antérieurs ont été correctement remboursés.
Il compte acheter avec son prêt des feuilles de tôles, des baguettes de soudures et des barres de fer. Cela pour ses prestations et la fabrique des portes isoprènes + fenêtres +  chaises qui seront mises à la vente.
Il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour  contribuer à l’amélioration de l’atelier, celle de la famille, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born around 1981 in Kai, Youssouf is married and the father of four. He lives with his family in the town of Loulouni, a subprefecture in the Sikasso region.
Youssouf has been doing metal work for about six years: welding and manufacturing of rubber doors, windows, and chairs for sale. He enjoys a good business reputation and receives many orders, but his resources do not allow him to meet demand. This is why he decided to collaborated with Soro Yiriwaso. He is on his fourth loan, having duly repaid the prior loans.

He plans to use his loan to buy iron sheets, welding roads and iron bars. These materials are needed  to manufacture rubber doors, windows and chairs  for sale. He plans to earn an average monthly revenue of 100,000 West African francs, which will be used to improve his workshop and his family’s life conditions and to pay off the interest on his loan, with the rest reinvested in his business.

loans.use: to buy iron sheets, welding roads and iron bars.

loans.name: Perla Nereyda

texts.es:
Doña perla es una micro empresaria que tiene aproximadamente diez años de producir tortillas suaves y tostadas, este producto es elaborado a base de maíz y constituye un alimento muy importante en la comida de los nicaragüenses.

Ella necesita un préstamo con el objetivo de comprar maíz y leña, esto con el objetivo de comprar el maíz por quintal y disminuir considerablemente los costos de producir este alimento. 

Antes de tener su propio negocio era estudiante, luego se casa donde tiene cuatro hijos, dos de ellos en edad escolar, para contribuir económicamente a su hogar y a su esposo, decide poner su propio negocio en su casa de habitación.

Con los ingresos que obtiene de su trabajo, le brinda seguridad alimentaria a sus hijos, además de los gastos personales del hogar y sus estudios.
texts.en:
Perla is a micro-entrepreneur who has been working making soft tortillas and tostadas for the past ten years.  This product is made from corn and makes up a very important nutritional item for the Nicaraguan diet.

She needs a loan in order to purchase corn and firewood.  Her goal is to buy corn in bulk and thus lower considerably the costs for producing her foods.  

Before running her own business she was a student.  Then she married and had four children, two of whom are still in school.  In order to contribute to her home and her husband, she decided to begin her own business in a room of her house.

With the income that she obtains from her work, she will provide food security for her children, as well as pay for household and educational expenses.

loans.use: To invest in the purchase of corn and firewood.

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda is 58-years-old and married with seven children.

Merlinda works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 16000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase canned goods, soft-drinks and other groceries.

Merlinda has borrowed and paid 21 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for twenty years and also earns an income from an Avon dealership.

Merlinda aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more canned goods, soft-drinks and other groceries.

loans.name: Julia

texts.es: Julia, de 28 años, es una mujer alegre y emprendedora, esta casada con Amiel , con quien tiene 02 pequeños hijos . Tiene su casa  propia en la cual vive cómodamente .El trabajo de Julia consiste en la venta de comida regional, se levanta temprano para ir al mercado a comprar todos los productos necesarios de la región y así poder empezar a preparar los deliciosos platillos que le coronan como la mejor en su zona .Su puesto de venta se encuentra en la vereda de su hogar ya que  acondicionó una zona para poder ofrecer sus productos. Lleva trabajando en este negocio por 08 años y desde que inicio trabaja sola ya que no tiene la compañía de ninguna otra persona.Le gusta su trabajo ya que le permite distraerse  y al mismo tiempo  genera sus ingresos económicos,  le está yendo bien en su trabajo, además siempre cuenta con clientela , espera empezar a vender en mayor cantidad y mejorar la infraestructura de sus muebles.Este será el segundo préstamo con MFP y está muy contenta ya que le brindaran un respaldo financiero y así podrá aumentar su capital de trabajo, sabe que tendrá que ser muy responsable y sobre todo puntual con el pago de sus cuotas .Con el monto solicitado de 1000 nuevos soles, comprará ingredientes e insumos tales como arroz, plátano, huevos, etc y algunos utensilios que necesita para continuar con su trabajo.
texts.en:
Julia, 28 year old, a happy woman and entrepreneur, is married to Amiel, with whom she has two small children. She has her own house in which she lives comfortably.

The work of Julia consists in the sale of local food, she gets up early in the morning to go to the market and buy all the necessary products of the region, so she can prepare the delicious dishes that crown her as the best in the area. 

Her food stand is located on the sidewalk of her home that she acconditioned to be able to offer her products. She has been working in this business for eigth years and since it started she had done it alone. Since she does not have the company of any other person.

She likes her work because it keeps her busy and at the same time generates income. She is doing well. In addition, she always have a good clientele and expects to begin selling in more and improve the infrastructure of her food stand. This will be the second loan with MFP and she is very happy because it will provide a financial backing and thus increase the working capital. 

She knows, she will have to be very responsible and above all timely with the payment of her dues .With the requested amount of 1000 new soles, she will buy ingredients such as rice, bananas, eggs, etc and some utensils she needs to continue with her work

loans.use: to buy ingredients such as rice, bananas, and eggs.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen is a 55-year-old married woman living with her seven children. She operates a piggery business and has been in this business for eight years. She would like to increase her sales as she will sell her pigs soon, and as a result she is borrowing a loan for PHP 8,000 to buy vitamins, feeds and vaccines to provide nourish and healthy pigs. She hopes to gain enough income to provide a good living to her family.

loans.use: to buy vitamins, feed and vaccines for her pigs.

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
This is Naomi from the Bethany Group. She is 40 years old. She trades in fast foods (fried rice). She has been doing this business for the past five years and is still doing very well. 

She always tells people good things about ID Ghana and how it has helped her overcome all her challenges in life. 

She is an innovative and hardworking individual who is also committed in all she does. She has been with ID for the past two years. 

This is her fifth loan, and she needs 1,400 GHS (Ghana cedis) to buy more goods to satisfy her customers in the Glefe community.

loans.use: to buy more rice to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Sonia Del Socorro

texts.es: Doña Sonia, mujer trabajadora continua con su pequeño negocio de pulpería y venta de tortillas a la par de su marido, ellos trabajan en conjunto para sacar adelante a sus dos hijos menores de edad, con su labor sin descanso logro que dos de sus hijos ya sean independientes, sus planes a futuros es poner  un puesto de tortilla y comida al mismo tiempo en la calle principal de su barrio aprovechando que es bien concurrida la zona. Solicita el crédito para seguir invirtiendo en su negocio comprando granos básicos, carnes, enlatados, gaseosas, maiz recargas telefónicas entre otros para cumplir con la demanda de los clientes.
texts.en:
Sonia is a hardworking woman. She is continuing with her small grocery store and tortilla sales, alongside her husband. They work together in order to get their two younger children ahead. By working without rest, they succeeded in having two of their children already be independent. 

Their plans for the future are to start a tortilla and food stall on their neighborhood’s main street, taking advantage of the fact that the area is well-traveled.

She is requesting a loan in order to continue investing in her business by purchasing basic grains, meat, canned goods, soft drinks, corn and phone chargers, among other items, in order to meet her customers’ demand.

loans.use: to purchase basic grains, meat, canned goods, soft drinks, phone chargers, and corn, among other items.

loans.name: Rujim

texts.en:
Rujim is 33 years old and single. He lives in Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He owns and operates a motorcycle-transport business to earn a living. He has been with his business for over three years and earns 15,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) every month. 

He joined GDMPC in 2007, and now he has requested a loan of 20,000 PHP to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. He hopes and dreams to have a better future.

loans.use: to repair a transport vehicle used in the business.

loans.name: Jeanette

texts.en:
Jeanette is 40 years old and married with one child. She lives in Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She owns and operates a business of growing flowers for sale in the local community to earn a living. She has been with her business for four years and earns 5,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) every month. 

She joined GDMPC in 2010, and now she has requested a loan of 7,000 PHP to purchase fertilizer such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure.

loans.name: Marife

texts.en:
This is Marife, 42, a resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Nelson, a driver, and is a mother to their children. She and her husband manage their household while operating the business. She and her husband are working hard to provide income for their everyday needs.

Marife sells different beauty products. She gets her products from a direct manufacturer with a lower cost, then sells them at a higher price. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 2,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 15,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy additional supplies and merchandise, like cologne, deodorant, perfume, soap and other products needed in her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Marife dreams to have her own factory for her products and hopes to have a good life. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for more beauty products and other merchandise needed in her business.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en: Francisca has been engaged in a hog-fattening business for over six years. She is 58 years old and a mother of two children. She is working hard to avoid experiencing the hardship of life. Thus, she is requesting a loan amount of 5,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) to buy feed and vitamins for her hogs. She is hoping that she could maximize these funds in order to improve her financial standing.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her hogs.

loans.name: Touch

texts.en:
Touch is 49 years old. She is married and resides with three children in Kampong Speu Province, Cambodia. She is a housekeeper. Her husband is a construction worker who makes an income of $5 daily. Two of her children are employed in the factory. They earn about $6 each day. 

Due to the difficulty with her family’s transportation, Touch is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase a motorbike for commuting. This purchase will help her reduce transportation expenses. In the future, she would like to run a grocery store at home and help her youngest child earn a higher education. Moreover, she hopes to build a new house, if possible.

loans.use: to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Analyn is married and works hard to support her family.

She earns a living by farming rice in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a general store and e-loading phone credits. Analyn is borrowing 29,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to buy more fertilizers for her rice field.

Analyn has been sustaining her business activities through her past 10 loans from NWTF and more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money and send her children in college.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers for her rice field.

loans.name: Leydy Melania

texts.es:
Leydy Melania de 26 años de edad, madre soltera con un hijo de dos meses de edad. Es originaria de Managua, lugar que está ubicado en la zona central del país. Leydy se caracteriza por ser una persona trabajadora, responsables, con ganas de superación personal. Mas en este momento que está experimentando el hecho de ser madres solteras, la cual tiene que luchar día  a día para el bienestar de su hija. Lamentablemente por falta de recursos económico no pudo cursar una carrera universitaria. Pero le hubiera gustado mucho estudiar enfermería titulada.
Gracia a su espíritu y sus ganas de salir adelante, es que tiene por actividad económica la venta de ropa nueva como pantalones, short, faldas, vestidos, blusas, camisetas, camisolas, ropa interior, juegos de sabanas, juegos de toallas. Actividad que la desempeña desde hace 8 años, en unos de los mercados de la localidad. El objetivo del crédito es invertir en capital de trabajo y surtir su negocio en la compra y venta de ropa nueva.  La rutina de trabajo de Leydi es trabajar unas 10 horas diarias. Para que en un futuro no muy lejano puedo obtener mejores ingresos.  Leydy agradece la ayuda que los inversionistas kiva les brindan a personas de escasos recursos y países pobre como es Nicaragua para tener un medio de trabajo digno.
texts.en:
Leydy Melania is a 26 year-old single mother with one child who is two months old. She is originally from Managua, which is located in the central zone of the country. Leydy is known for being a hard working, responsible person with a desire for self-improvement -- now more than ever, as she is experiencing the reality of being a single mother. She has to fight day in and day out for the well-being of her child. Unfortunately, due to a lack of economic resources, she was not able to pursue a university degree. However, she would have really liked to have studied for a nursing degree. 

Thanks to her spirit and desire to get ahead, she sells new clothing like pants, shorts, skirts, dresses, blouses, t-shirts, camisoles, and undergarments, as well as sheet and towel sets. She has been doing this work for eight years, at one of the markets in her town. Her goal with this loan is to invest in working capital and to stock her clothing business. Leydy's work routine is to work ten hours a day so that some day in the not-too-distant future she can obtain better income. Leydy is grateful for the help that Kiva lenders are offering to people with scarce resources in poor countries like Nicaragua, so that they can work with dignity.

loans.use: to stock her store with new clothing like pants, shorts, skirts, dresses, blouses, t-shirts, camisoles, and undergarments, as well as sheet and towel sets

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy basic grains, snacks, sodas, baked goods, personal hygiene products, and other household items.

loans.name: Phalla

texts.en: Phalla is 43-years-old. She is married and resides with three children in Kampong Speu Province, Cambodia. She has been selling food for more than three years, earning approximately $10 daily. Her husband is a police officer who earns about $4 per day. Due to lack of funds, Phalla is requesting a loan of $900 to purchase zinc to build the roof of her house. This money will help make her house much better. In the future, she would like to expand her food store and help her children earn their bachelor’s degree.

loans.use: to purchase zinc to build the roof of her house.

loans.name: Sandra Marixa

texts.es:
Sandra es una mujer de 40 años de edad casada que de su matrimonio tiene 5 hijos los cuales están en diferentes grados de educación en la primaria y un mayor el cual trabaja con sus padres en la siembra y cultivo de café todos vive en casa como una gran familia. Ella tiene un nivel de educación primaria completa la cual con mucho esfuerzo y sacrificio por parte de sus padres mismos que le enseñaron a muy temprana edad la actividad del cultivo. Junto a su esposos trabaja en la agricultura desde hace mas de 7 años estando sus cultivos a una distancia de su casa de 2 kilómetros trasladándose a pie diariamente sin olvidar el apoyo de sus hijos al salir de sus actividades escolares diariamente. Su producto es comercializado y vendido en el mercado local en pequeña escala y con algunos compradores que vienen de otras regiones cercanas al lugar donde ella habita.

Actualmente solicita ayuda para la compra de insumos como ser bombas para fumigación, abono natural mismos que ayudaran a mantener sano su cultivo de enfermedades como la roya y algunas plagas que deterioran toda la siembra.

Sus metas y sus sueños son de poder seguirles dando a sus hijos una mejor educación que esta sea el arma que ellos puedan utilizar para poder defenderse ante los retos de la vida y poder seguir adelante para que cada uno de ellos pueda cumplir sus sueños y metas y pasar la mejor enseñanza que existe El respeto a Dios, la educación y los principios que son la base para el éxito en la vida.
texts.en:
Sandra is a 40-year-old married woman. From that marriage, she has five children who are in different grades of primary school. The oldest works with Sandra and her husband in the planting and cultivation of coffee. They all live together like a big family. Sandra completed the primary level of education thanks to the great effort and sacrifice of her own parents, who taught her the business of coffee cultivation from a very early age. 

Together with husband, Sandra has worked in agriculture for more than seven years. Her crops are more than two kilometers from her house and she travels to them on foot daily, without forgetting to support her children when they get out of school every day. Her crops are marketed and sold on a small scale in the local market and to some buyers who come to the place where she lives from other nearby regions.

Sandra is currently requesting help to purchase supplies like fumigation pumps and natural fertilizers to help keep her crops healthy and free of diseases like coffee rust and other infestations that deteriorate the entire crop.

Her goals and her dreams are to be able to continue giving her children a better education, as this will be the weapon that they can use to defend themselves against the challenges of life; to be able to keep moving forward so that each of them can achieve their dreams and goals; and to pass on the best teachings of all: respect for God, education, and the principles that are the basis for success in life.

loans.use: to purchase supplies like fumigation pumps and natural fertilizer for her coffee crops.

loans.name: Junalyn

texts.en:
This is Junalyn; she is 29-years-old and a resident of Silang, Cavite Philippines. She is married to Francis and is the mother to their children. She and her husband manage their own household. At this time, she is working hard to provide income continually for her everyday expenses.  

Junalyn oversees and owns operations of their tricycle transportation business. They have one tricycle that carries up to four passengers to their destination within the community. The tricycle driver then remits a boundary (daily quota) each day to her. In her business, the regular customers are the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 15,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy spare parts and accessories, and also to maintain their motorcycle. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Junalyn dreams to have more tricycles and hopes to give her children a good life and education. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her life and business every week where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for the spare parts and maintenance of their tricycle unit.

loans.name: An

texts.en: An is 33-years-old. She is single and resides with her brother and sister in Kampong Speu Province, Cambodia. She has been working in a garment factory for more than ten years, earning approximately $4 daily. Her brother is employed at a rice mill. He earns about $3 daily. Her sister is also employed in garment factory and earns about $4 per day. In order to improve her family’s finances, An took out a loan of $1300 to purchase a motorbike for her brother to run a taxi service. This purchase will help him generate additional income for the family. In the future, she would like to run an additional business and rebuild her house to make it much stronger to provide better living conditions for her family.

loans.use: to purchase a motorbike for her brother to run the taxi service.

loans.name: Lorelie

texts.en:
As a married mother of four children, Lorelie works hard to support her family.

She has a ready-to-wear retail business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from rice retailing. Lorelie is borrowing PHP 18000 through NWTF to purchase more items like blouses, t-shirts, pants, slippers, and other ready-to-wear items.

Lorelie has been sustaining her business activities through her past five loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more items like blouses, t-shirts, pants, slippers, and other ready-to-wear clothing.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is married and works hard to support her family.  She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from Avon and Natasha dealership. Jocelyn is borrowing PHP 11,000 through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. to purchase more stocks to sell at her store.

Jocelyn has been sustaining her business activities through her past five loans from NWTF and more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks to sell.

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.es: Benjamín es fabricante de calzado,  cuando requirió dinero para comprar su maquina de coser   recurrió a su credikiva, hoy con su nueva máquina ha logrado mejorar la calidad de producto y disminuyó sus tiempos de producción. Su negocio hoy es mucho mas visitado por nuevos clientes que cada día que pasa,  hacen mas pedidos y su capital  de trabajo no es suficiente para responder prontamente a esa demanda;   para obtener mejores precios por la compra de sus materias primas e insumos en mayor volumen. Esta es la razón por la cual hoy acude a un nuevo credikiva, con el  cual comprará capelladas, pegantes y otros insumos con los cuales  aumentará su capacidad productiva y será mas efectiva en dar respuesta a su distinguida clientela.
texts.en:
Benjamín is a shoemaker. When he needed money to buy his sewing machine, he turned to a Kiva loan. Today, with his new machine, he has managed to improve the quality of his product and reduce his production time. His business today is much busier, with new customers coming in every day. 

His customers are ordering more, and Benjamín's working capital is insufficient to respond promptly to that demand. To get better prices, he needs to purchase his raw materials and supplies in greater volume. This is the reason that today he is turning to Kiva for another loan so that he can buy shoe uppers, adhesives, and other supplies to increase his production capacity and to be more effective in responding to his distinguished customers.

loans.use: to by shoe uppers, adhesives, and other supplies.

loans.name: Virgen Del Socabon Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “VIRGEN DEL SOCABON”  iniciará el tercer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Villa Tejada, está compuesta por siete integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Fermina es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de comida, comercio de verduras, tejido a máquina, venta de silpancho.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Fermina es integrante, ella indica que hace cinco años que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de una amiga que es socia de la institución. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de lejía (dulce para el mascado de coca); cuenta que este negocio lo emprendió hace varios años, por iniciativa de su tía que realizaba estos productos, posteriormente decide aperturar su propio espacio de venta.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de harina, azúcar y ceniza) que adquirirá de las ferias de la ciudad de El Alto y posteriormente a la elaboración lo comercializara en su puesto de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para mantener en lo posible a su hogar pues ella es casada y tiene dos hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta las capacitaciones y compartir con las compañeras.

En la fotografía no esta presente la señora Lidia, ya que se encontraba en consulta médica
texts.en:
The "Virgen del Socabon" communal bank will begin its third cycle in Pro Mujer as part of the Villa Tejada regional office. It is made up of seven members and is directed by a board of directors, of which Fermina is the president. The businesses that the members of the communal bank run are varied, and include food sales, vegetable sales, machine weaving, and selling "silpancho" [a traditional Bolivian meal of beef, rice, and potatoes]. 

The loan that they will take out will benefit small-business owners like Fermina. She says that she became part of Por Mujer five years ago, joining on the invitation of a friend who is a member of the institution. Currently, she has a business selling "lejia," a sweet substance chewed along with coca leaves. She says that she started this business several years ago at the suggestion of her aunt, who was making this product. Later, she decided to open her own sales stall.

The loan that she will now take out will increase her capital for buying flour, sugar, and ash, which she will acquire in the street fairs of the city of El Alto; after making the product, she will sell it in her sales stall. This kind of work allows her to generate resources for maintaining her home as well as possible, as she is married and has two children.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she responds that she likes the training and sharing with her fellow members.

Lidia is not pictured in the photograph, as she had a doctor's appointment.

loans.use: to buy flour, sugar, and ash.

loans.name: Nena

texts.en: Nena is a hard working mother who engages in hog-raising to help her husband in financing the education of their seven children. As a responsible parent, they aim to educate their children and give them a better life. Due to the high cost of school fees, Nena aimed to strengthen the business and generate sufficient income. Due to financial insufficiency, she is asking for additional capital of P 30,000 to buy feed, vitamins and additional piglets to raise. She is hoping that her loan will be a great help for her to improve the business and hoping that someday, she will make it more viable and profitable.

loans.use: to buy feed, vitamins and additional piglets to raise.

loans.name: Ofelia

texts.en: Ofelia is from the peaceful village of Sta. Cruz. She is 53 years old, and is married to Mamerto. The couple is thankful because they had been blessed with four healthy children. To support her family, Ofelia is engaged in selling vegetables around their village. She has been in this business for three years, and earns PHP 2,500 a week. She wants to expand her business. To this end, Ofelia is asking for a loan in the amount of PHP 30,000 to buy more onions to sell. She hopes that she can obtain the requested loan to improve her business and give her children a good quality of life.

loans.use: to buy more onions to sell.

loans.name: Vanessa

texts.en: Vanessa and her husband are blessed with three children and they live in the village of Centro 1. She has requested a loan of PHP 50,000 to purchase feed and additional piglets to support her business. Her goal is to expand her pig-raising business to maintain her income and support the needs of her family. Vanessa said she must be strong and work hard in order to achieve her dreams, just like well-known entrepreneurs.

loans.use: to purchase feed and additional piglets to support her business.

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina works hard to support her family. Angelina is married and has a fish vending business in the Philippines.

Angelina requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to buy more fish to sell.
Angelina has been in this business for 45 years now.

In the future, Angelina would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Rosana

texts.en: Rosana is 53 years old, married with 2 children. She lives in Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She owns and operates a fish selling business in the local community to earn a living. She has been with her business for over 9 years and earns 35,000 PHP every month. She has been a member of GDMPC since 2009 and now she has requested a loan of 44,000 PHP to purchase additional fish and shrimp to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish and shrimp to sell.

loans.name: Jenie

texts.en: Jenie is a devoted wife. She expresses her commitment and full devotion to her business and to her family as well. Jenie has operated a small sari-sari (variety) store for eight years. The profits earned from her businesses allow her to pay school fees and allowances for her children. At this moment, Jenie wants to strengthen her business but has inadequate funds, so she is asking for a loan of 50,000 PHP to buy soap, shampoo, canned goods, soft drinks, vinegar, and other basic kitchen items. She wants to stock more items in her store to meet all her customers' requests. In the future, Jenie aims to have a larger store to earn higher revenue. She wants to achieve financial independence.

loans.use: to buy soap, shampoo, canned goods, soft drinks, vinegar, and other basic kitchen items for her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Venilda

texts.en: Venilda is 52 years old and a married mother of seven children. She continues to run her school snack bar located in a study center. The previous loans she has asked for have been very useful for investing in the business. With this loan she will do the same, as this is the only way of survival for her and her children. She will buy sodas, candy and cookies in order to improve the inventory of her business. The income will be used for her children's studies, which is her priority.

loans.use: to buy sodas, candy and cookies for her snack bar.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is 50 years old, married and has nine children. Two of their children are in school.
Josephine is in the agricultural business of raising pigs in the Philippines. Josephine requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.
Josephine has been raising pigs for five years now, and has borrowed three times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.
In the future, Josephine would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Anchata

texts.fr:
Née vers 1983 à Sikasso, Madame Anchata  est mariée et mère de 3 enfants et réside avec son époux et leurs enfants dans une famille nucléaire à Sanoubougou I, un des  quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso.
Après plusieurs activités sans succès, elle s’est initiée depuis plus de six années à cette activité de petit commerce notamment à l’achat et à la  vente d’habillements (pagne wax, tissus brodé.) de sacs à main etc. Elle achète ses marchandises à Bobo Dioulasso (au Burkina Faso) avant de les revendre à sa place au marché de leur localité où ses marchandises sont beaucoup sollicitées de sa clientèle (composée essentiellement de femmes de ménages et de vendeuses du marché ) pour leur qualité.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus d’une année. Ainsi, elle sollicite un deuxième crédit pour augmenter son fonds de commerce afin d’acheter 15 pièces de pagne wax, 10 complets de tissus brodé et 10 sacs à main.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce crédit un bénéfice mensuel de 70 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs. Anchata was born circa 1983 in Sikasso. She's married and the mother of three children. She lives with her husband and their children in a nuclear family in Sanoubougou I, an outlying neighborhood in Sikasso.

After unsuccessfully trying several businesses, she started her retail business six years ago. She buys and sells clothing such as Wax pagnes (colorful African cloth) and embroidered fabrics, as well as other items such as handbags.

She gets her supplies in Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso) and resells at her spot at the local market. Thanks to their quality, her products are in high demand from her clientele, which comprises mostly housekeepers and market sellers. 

Eager to better meet an ever-increasing customer demand, she decided one year ago to join Kiva's partner, the MFI Soro Yiriwaso. She's now seeking her second loan in order to bolster her working capital and buy 15 lengths of Wax pagnes, 10 embroidered suits, and 10 handbags.

Thanks to her loan, she intends to turn an average monthly profit of XOF 70'000 (ca US$ 140), to be used mainly to contribute to the family's expenses and pay the interests on her loan. She will invest the remainder in her business.

loans.use: to buy 15 lengths of Wax pagnes (colorful African cloth), 10 embroidered suits, and 10 handbags

loans.name: Kansé

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Kansé  a plus de 36 ans, marié et père de deux  enfants, il réside avec sa famille à Sanoubougou I, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Kansé après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès,  s’est initié au commerce  d articles divers : de Prêt à Porter, Chaussures et des articles d’’Alimentation à la gare routière de Sikasso. Il est dans cette activité il y’a environ vingt, depuis très jeune. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  il est à son sixième prêt individuel.
Ce sixième prêt lui permettra d’acheter 40 chemises différentes, 25 pantalons de qualité différentes, 25 paires de chaussures différentes (Soulier, Ferardine), 10 complets de veste, 10 Tee-Shirt et 10 complets de sous-vêtement. Il s’approvisionne auprès de commerçants grossistes à Bamako avant de les revendre en détail à une clientèle composée généralement des voyageurs et surtout de routiers.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Kansé is over 36 years old. He is married and the father of two children. He lives with his family in Sanoubougou I, one of the neighborhoods of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

After conducting several unsuccessful activities, Mr. Kansé began trading sundry items: ready-to-wear, shoes and grocery items at the Sikasso bus station. He became active in this business at an early age, some 20 years ago. He is much sought after by his customers for the quality of his products. 

To satisfy an increasing number of customers, he decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution, where he is on his sixth individual loan.

This sixth loan will enable him to buy 40 different shirts, 25 slacks of varying qualities, 25 different pairs of shoes (brands such as Soulier and Ferardine), 10 jackets, 10 T-shirts and 10 full sets of underwear. 

He buys from wholesalers in Bamako before reselling retail to customers who are for the most part travelers and bus drivers.

He expects to make monthly profits of 150,000 FCFA which will be used to contribute to family expenses and pay interest on the loan. The remainder will be invested in his business activity.

loans.use: buy ready-to-wear and shoes

loans.name: Mabita

texts.es:
Mabita, de 45 años es una mujer trabajadora. Vive en compañía de su esposo Emilio, con quien tiene 2 hijos, pero solo vive con uno de ellos: Kevin a quien cuida en la casa que compró hace 25 años. 
Cuando formó su familia pensó en comenzar un negocio, por ese motivo empezó a generar ingresos con cualquier necesidad de los pobladores, comprando pomada para los zapatos, peines, sujetadores para ropa y demás accesorios. En los primeros años obtenía pocas ganancias pero conforme pasaron los años ideó una mejor manera de vender, es así que alquiló un pequeño espacio en la plaza del pueblo, donde trabaja desde hace 20 años a la actualidad, le va muy bien en su trabajo y según cuenta espera dentro de poco poder obtener el capital de trabajo para abrir una tienda propia, donde pueda seguir vendiendo diversos accesorios para el hogar, ahora desea comprar productos para la escuela, pues comienzan las clases. Mabita,en esta oportunidad solicita S/2500 soles , para la compra de productos que le hacen falta en su negocio tales como peines, útiles de escritorio , varios ganchos y cintas para sujetar el cabello de los alumnos y asi hacer que su negocio siga progresando.
texts.en:
Mabita, 45, is a hard-working woman who lives with her husband, Emilio.  They have two children, but only one still lives at home, Kevin.  She cares for him in the house they bought 25 years ago.

When she began her family she thought about starting a business and began generating an income based on community needs.  She bought shoe polish, combs, clothes hangers and other accessories.  In the early years profits were small, but as years went buy she figured out a better way to sell.  She rented a small space in the town plaza where she has been working now for 20 years.  Her business is flourishing and she hopes to be able to obtain enough capital to open a store where she can continue selling home accessories.  Now she wants to buy school materials because classes are about to begin.

On this occasion, Mabita is requesting a loan of 2,500 PEN to buy items she needs for the business, such as combs, desk supplies, hair pins and ribbons and other products to keep her business prospering.

loans.use: To buy products such as combs, hair pins, school materials, etc.

loans.name: Cooperativa Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “COOPERATIVA”  iniciará el séptimo ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Panamericana, está compuesta por ocho integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Manuela es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: comercio de frutas, venta de cordones y pitas, venta de ropa deportiva, costura de chamarras, trenzado de mantas, venta de sogas, artesanía, tienda de barrio.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Manuela es integrante, ella indica que hace tres años y medio que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de un promotor de la institución que fue a visitarle a su casa. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de tienda de barrio; da a conocer que este negocio lo implementó con el primer préstamo que hizo en Pro Mujer y en la actualidad de va muy bien.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de cereales, aceites, conservas) que adquirirá de las tiendas distribuidoras de la ciudad de La Paz y posteriormente lo comercializará en su espacio de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para mantener en lo posible a su hogar pues ella es viuda y tiene tres hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta el área de salud.
texts.en:
The communal bank "COOPERATIVA" will begin its seventh Pro Mujer loan cycle, through the Panamerican Social Center.  The group is comprised of eight members with a management board is led by Manuela, the president.  The members are involved in different businesses such as sales of fruit, jewelry, sport clothes, and rope, and coat making, blanket weaving and running a grocery store.

The loan requested will benefit the group of small business owners that Manuela belongs to.  She says she has been a member of Pro Mujer for three and half years and joined through invitation from an insititutional promoter that visited her at home.  She now runs a neighborhood grocery store that she began with her first loan through Pro Mujer.  Business is doing very well.

The loan requested now is to increase capital to buy cereals, oils and canned goods from the distributors in the city of La Paz.  Then she will sell the products at her store.  This will allow her to generate enough income to support her household, since she is a widow with three children.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she says it is the health area.

loans.use: To buy cereals, oils and canned goods.

loans.name: Delmy Yasmin

texts.es:
Delmy tiene 35 años de edad, esta acompañada y tiene tres hijos. Ella trabaja en un comedor de la ciudad; pues los ingresos de su esposo que trabaja en la agricultura no son suficientes para cubrir los gastos de sus tres hijos. 

El préstamo que esta solicitando a Fundación Campo, es para comprar ladrillos, cemento, arena; para construir una pila para almacenar agua. Debido a que el agua la tiene que almacenar en recipientes plásticos y no le son suficientes. De esta manera, mejorara la salubridad de su familia al utilizar el agua para lavarse las manos, bañarse y para los oficios de casa. Su próximo paso es mejorar su vivienda para brindar comodidad a su familia.
texts.en:
Delmy, 35, lives with her common-law husband and their three children.  She works in a city diner because her husband's income from his agriculture business is not enough to cover expenses for the three children.

The loan she is requesting through Fundación Campo is to buy bricks, cement and sand to build a water deposit.  She now stores water in plastic containers which is not a sufficient method.  This way she will be able to improve her family's healthy as they will have water to wash their hands, bathe and use for other household purposes.  Her goal is to make home improvements for her family's comfort.

loans.use: To buy bricks, cement and sand to build a water deposit.

loans.name: Ana Del Carmen

texts.es:
Ana tiene 32 años de edad, esta soltera. Ella vive junto a su madre y su hermana; Ana no escucha muy bien y su hermana es la que esta pendiente de ella. Trabaja en un cafetín en el parque central de la ciudad, vende pupusas, tostadas de plátano y bebidas. 

Desde hace unos cuatro años que esta trabajando en el cafetín, comenzó ayudándole a su hermana y como vio que ella trabajaba bien le dejo el negocio y ella estableció otro; es decir que las dos tienen negocio propio. 

El préstamo que esta solicitando a Fundación Campo, es para cancelar una deuda con otra institución y para comprar más mercadería para el cafetín ya que se aproxima la semana de vacación, comprara panes con pollo, dos vinagreras, platos descartables. Sin el préstamo, no podría comprar más insumos para el negocio, ya que sale ajustada con los gastos del hogar. Lo que desea hacer es comprar una plancha para elaborar y vender pupusas.
texts.en:
Ana, 32, is single.  She lives with her mother and sister, who watches out for Ana because of her hearing impairment.  She works in a cafe in the central park of the city, selling pupusas (stuffed tortillas), banana snacks and beverages.

For four years she has been working at the cafe and started out by helping her sister.  Since her sister saw that Ana worked well, she left her the business and established another one.  So both of them have their own businesses.

The loan she is requesting through Fundación Campo is to pay off another loan and to buy goods for the cafe for the upcoming holiday week.  She will buy bread, chicken, two oil and vinegar bottles, and disposable plates.  Without the loan she would not be able to buy more supplies for her business because she has just enough to cover household expenses.  Her goal is to buy a grill to make and sell pupusas.

loans.use: To pay back another loan and buy goods for her cafe.  The holiday week is coming and she wants to buy bread, chicken, oil and vinegar bottles and disposable plates.

loans.name: Unión Progreso 2 Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “UNIÓN PROGRESO”  iniciará el décimo sexto ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Senkata, está compuesta por ocho integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Alejandrina es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de abarrotes, venta de zapatos, venta de polleras, venta de rutas, venta de ropa, venta de comida, venta de tejidos.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Alejandrina es integrante, ella indica que hace dos años que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de su amiga que es socia de la institución. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de comida; da a conocer que este negocio lo emprendió por iniciativa propia, empezando con un poco capital.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de arroz, papa y fideos) que adquirirá de las vendedoras mayoristas de la ciudad de La Paz, posteriormente a la elaboración lo comercializará en su puesto de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para mantener en lo posible a su hogar pues ella vive en unión libre y tiene dos hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta le gusta las capacitaciones en salud y crédito.
texts.en:
The communal bank "UNIÓN PROGRESO" will begin its sixth Pro Mujer loan cycle at the Senkata Social Center.  The group is comprised of eight members and their management board is led by Alejandrina, the president.  The members of the group are involved in different business activities, such as selling shoes, chickens, itineraries, clothing, food and woven products.

The loan will benefit the group of small business owners that Alejandrina belongs to.  She says she has been in Pro Mujer for two years and joined by invitation from a friend who is a member of the institution.
